Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: Several reports, including a meta-analysis of 15 studies (12,320 patients), demonstrate that rectal culture-directed antimicrobial prophylaxis, based on pre-biopsy screening for resistant pathogens, is an effective and reasonable approach to reduce post-biopsy infectious complications in TRPB patients, lowering incidence from 3.4% with empirical prophylaxis to 0.8% with targeted prophylaxis. A separate multicenter, randomized controlled trial enrolled 403 TRPB patients with low risks of infectious complications, adhering to current criteria. (Confidence: 100.0%)

Content: FQ Resistance Drives Targeted Prophylaxis in Prostate Biopsy
Assessment: How consistent/coherent is the cluster?

Content: Fluoroquinolones (FQs) are suspended for prostate biopsy by the European Commission due to increased resistance, yet targeted therapy based on rectal swab microbiology significantly reduces infectious complications in cases of FQ resistance (9 RCTs, 3,096 patients). While cephalosporins or aminoglycosides can be used as alternatives with comparable infectious complications where FQs are suspended (2 RCTs), the applicability of targeted prophylaxis to non-FQ antibiotics is unclear, with no RCTs available for non-FQ targeted prophylaxis; consequently, specific agent recommendations are not made due to global variations in pathogens, susceptibility, and antibiotic availability. (Confidence: 100.0%)
